subject: Only add "on-link" routes for L2 adjacent subnets
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-02-25 10:16:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/a57248784289f59240e5f355a920175c8ff90284', 'message': 'Make "on-link" routes for subnets optional

When adding multiple subnets on a single network the
dhcp agent will set dhcp-options to advertise
"on-link"/"same-segment" classless static routes to
all the subnets. This change add a new configuration
option 'enable_on_link_subnet_routes' that enables
the operator to disable the creation of the "on-link"
routes.

This behaviour does not always make sense. When using
Ironic for baremetal provisioning the baremetal nodes
might be on a different L2 broadcast segment with a
DHCP-relay. In this used-case the "on-link" routes
are undesireable.

Change-Id: Iae889e9226a61059cd4f3d37fbe48d013b7a3482
Implements: blueprint tripleo-routed-networks-ironic-inspector

routes.

According to rfc3442 configuring the DHCP server to
specify these routes is optional.

 Local Subnet Routes

     In some cases more than one IP subnet may be configured on a link.
     In such cases, a host whose IP address is in one IP subnet in the
     link could communicate directly with a host whose IP address is in a
     different IP subnet on the same link. In cases where a client is
     being assigned an IP address on an IP subnet on such a link, for each
     IP subnet in the link other than the IP subnet on which the client
     has been assigned the DHCP server MAY be configured to specify a
     router IP address of 0.0.0.0.

Closes-Bug: #1668145
Change-Id: Iae889e9226a61059cd4f3d37fbe48d013b7a3482
Implements: blueprint tripleo-routed-networks-ironic-inspector

commit_message:
Only add "on-link" routes for L2 adjacent subnets

When multiple subnets exist on a single network, the
DHCP agent adds on-link routes for all of them since
they are in the same L2 network.  If either subnet
has a segment_id it can only be considered as on-link
if they match, else we should not include a subnet
route.

These extra routes are optional anyways according to
RFC 3442, but were added for the use case when all of
the subnets are considered adjacent, which allows
instances to bypass the router and communicate directly.

Closes-Bug: #1668145
Change-Id: Iae889e9226a61059cd4f3d37fbe48d013b7a3482
Implements: blueprint tripleo-routed-networks-deployment
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/71/438171/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - "On-Link" or "Same-Segment" routes added to dhcp-options is now optional. Dhcp agent configuration has a new option 'enable_on_link_subnet_routes' that can be used to enable/disable the creation of classless static routes; "on-link" host routes; for subnets on the same Neutron network.

commit_message:
Fix doc generation for Python3

Fix the Sphinx html_last_updated_fmt for Python3.
The html_last_updated_fmt option is interpeted as a
byte string in python3, causing Sphinx build to break.
This patch makes it utf-8 string.

Change-Id: I9acc4200751e63fa29be738cfa00c4637efd8287
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/34/457234/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Do not sync suffixes when remote rejects reconstructor revert
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-02-16 23:45:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/47f6d3af04b725a47e8c6906762a90691d020556', 'message': 'Do not sync suffixes when remote rejects reconstructor revert

SSYNC is designed to limit concurrent incoming connections in order to
prevent IO contention.  The reconstructor should expect remote
replication servers to fail ssync_sender when the remote is too busy.
When the remote rejects ssync - it should avoid forcing additional IO
against the remote with a REPLICATE request which causes suffix
rehashing.

Suffix rehashing via REPLICATE verbs takes two forms:

1) a initial pre-flight call to REPLICATE /dev/part will cause a remote
primary to rehash any invalid suffixes and return a map for the local
sender to compare so that a sync can be performed on any mis-matched
suffixes.

2) a final call to REPLICATE /dev/part/suf1-suf2-suf3[-sufX[...]] will
cause the remote primary to rehash the *given* suffixes even if they are
*not* invalid.  This is a requirement for rsync replication because
after a suffix is synced via rsync the contents of a suffix dir will
likely have changed and the remote server needs to update it hashes.pkl
to reflect the new data.

SSYNC does *need* to to send a post sync REPLICATE request - any
suffixes that are modified by the SSYNC protocol will call _finalize_put
under the hood as it is syncing.  It is however not harmful and
potentially useful to go ahead refresh hashes after an SSYNC while the
inodes of those suffixes are warm in the cache.

However, that only makes sense if the SSYNC conversation actually synced
any suffixes - if ssync sender is rejected for concurrency before it
ever got started there is no value in the remote performing a rehash.
It is in fact not un-likely that *another* reconstructor is pushing data
into that same partition and the suffixes will become immediately
invalidated.

If a ssync_sender does not successful finish a sync we should skip the
REPLICATE call entirely and move on to the next partition without
causing any useless remote IO.

Closes-Bug: #1665141

Change-Id: Ia72c407247e4525ef071a1728750850807ae8231

commit_message:
Do not sync suffixes when remote rejects reconstructor revert

SSYNC is designed to limit concurrent incoming connections in order to
prevent IO contention.  The reconstructor should expect remote
replication servers to fail ssync_sender when the remote is too busy.
When the remote rejects SSYNC - it should avoid forcing additional IO
against the remote with a REPLICATE request which causes suffix
rehashing.

Suffix rehashing via REPLICATE verbs takes two forms:

1) a initial pre-flight call to REPLICATE /dev/part will cause a remote
primary to rehash any invalid suffixes and return a map for the local
sender to compare so that a sync can be performed on any mis-matched
suffixes.

2) a final call to REPLICATE /dev/part/suf1-suf2-suf3[-sufX[...]] will
cause the remote primary to rehash the *given* suffixes even if they are
*not* invalid.  This is a requirement for rsync replication because
after a suffix is synced via rsync the contents of a suffix dir will
likely have changed and the remote server needs to update it hashes.pkl
to reflect the new data.

SSYNC does not *need* to send a post-sync REPLICATE request.  Any
suffixes that are modified by the SSYNC protocol will call _finalize_put
under the hood as it is syncing.  It is however not harmful and
potentially useful to go ahead refresh hashes after an SSYNC while the
inodes of those suffixes are warm in the cache.

However, that only makes sense if the SSYNC conversation actually synced
any suffixes - if SSYNC is rejected for concurrency before it ever got
started there is no value in the remote performing a rehash.  It may be
that *another* reconstructor is pushing data into that same partition
and the suffixes will become immediately invalidated.

If a ssync_sender does not successful finish a sync the reconstructor
should skip the REPLICATE call entirely and move on to the next
partition without causing any useless remote IO.

Closes-Bug: #1665141

Change-Id: Ia72c407247e4525ef071a1728750850807ae8231

added_lines: def _make_fake_ssync(self, ssync_calls, fail_jobs=None): """ Replace SsyncSender with a thin Fake. :param ssync_calls: an empty list, a non_local, all calls to ssync will be captured for assertion in the caller. :param fail_jobs: optional iter of dicts, any job passed into Fake that matches a failure dict will return success == False. """ self.success = True for failure in fail_jobs: if all(job.get(k) == v for (k, v) in failure.items()): self.success = False break context['success'] = self.success return self.success, self.available_map def test_no_delete_failed_revert(self): # test will only process revert jobs self.reconstructor.handoffs_only = True captured_ssync = [] # fail all jobs on part 2 on sda1 fail_jobs = [ {'device': 'sda1', 'partition': 2}, ] with mock.patch('swift.obj.reconstructor.ssync_sender', self._make_fake_ssync( captured_ssync, fail_jobs=fail_jobs)), \ mocked_http_conn(*[200, 200], body=pickle.dumps({})) as request_log: self.reconstructor.reconstruct() # global setup has four revert jobs self.assertEqual(len(captured_ssync), 4) expected_ssync_calls = set([ # device, part, frag_index ('sda1', 2, 2), ('sda1', 2, 0), ('sda1', 0, 2), ('sda1', 1, 1), ]) self.assertEqual(expected_ssync_calls, set([ (context['job']['device'], context['job']['partition'], context['job']['frag_index']) for context in captured_ssync ])) self.assertEqual(2, len(request_log.requests)) expected_suffix_calls = [] for context in captured_ssync: if not context['success']: # only successful jobs generate suffix rehash calls continue job = context['job'] expected_suffix_calls.append( (job['sync_to'][0]['replication_ip'], '/%s/%s/%s' % ( job['device'], job['partition'], '-'.join(job['suffixes']))) ) self.assertEqual(set(expected_suffix_calls), set((r['ip'], r['path']) for r in request_log.requests)) mocked_http_conn() as request_log: # failed ssync job should not generate a suffix rehash self.assertEqual([], request_log.requests) mocked_http_conn() as request_log: # failed ssync job should not generate a suffix rehash self.assertEqual([], request_log.requests)
deleted_lines: def _make_fake_ssync(self, ssync_calls): return True, self.available_map mock.patch('swift.obj.diskfile.ECDiskFileManager._get_hashes', return_value=(None, stub_hashes)), \ mocked_http_conn(*[200] * len(expected_suffix_calls), body=pickle.dumps({})) as request_log: found_suffix_calls = set((r['ip'], r['path']) for r in request_log.requests) self.assertEqual(expected_suffix_calls, found_suffix_calls) expected_suffix_calls = set([ (sync_to[0]['replication_ip'], '/%s/0/123-abc' % sync_to[0]['device']) ]) mock.patch('swift.obj.diskfile.ECDiskFileManager._get_hashes', return_value=(None, stub_hashes)), \ mocked_http_conn(*[200] * len(expected_suffix_calls), body=pickle.dumps({})) as request_log: found_suffix_calls = set((r['ip'], r['path']) for r in request_log.requests) self.assertEqual(expected_suffix_calls, found_suffix_calls)

commit_message:
add configuration instructions from admin guide and dev docs

- move cinder and keystone configuration instructions from admin
guide to install guide so we have all meter enabling steps in
same place.
- move heat and neutron config to install guide.

Change-Id: Ibc8096e3fb6c95886c3bddafb927600fe506415d

commit_message:
Fix oslo.messaging log level

The default log level of oslo.messaging was set on the python package
name, which means it didn't take effect for all logs. This fixes it
adding it on the namespace name as well.

Related-Bug: #1685148
Change-Id: I0263717b9fd4d3c6ee4083c71df9b4b26401a39b

commit_message:
Update all SHAs for 14.2.3

This patch updates all the roles to the latest available stable
SHA's, copies the release notes from the updated roles into the
integrated repo, updates all the OpenStack Service SHA's, and
updates the appropriate python requirements pins.

Depends-On: I57f99d91fafd35ec0a3dac5461c3c984eab6c634
Change-Id: I2c5ac614c0acd8bafeac214e26a894718af2dcdf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/66/461066/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - New variables have been added to allow a deployer to customize a heat systemd unit file to their liking. - The task dropping the heat systemd unit files now uses the ``config_template`` action plugin allowing deployers access to customize the unit files as they see fit without having to load extra options into the defaults and polute the generic systemd unit file with jinja2 variables and conditionals.

commit_message:
make default python for venv python 3

We use the venv tox target as a generic environment for running commands
defined in this repo. Let's redefine the environment to use python 3 by
default.

Change-Id: I0cf5f50b7d36f5ebb61408eefeccb702432464be
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
make USE_SCREEN=False imply USE_SYSTEMD=True

In order to start making the transition in the gate make
USE_SCREEN=False also mean USE_SYSTEMD=True. We'll never actually
declare USE_SYSTEMD=True in the gate (as that doesn't exist for stable
branches), but this will let us roll over the existing transition.

We also have to install systemd-python 234 because we are recording
exception info in the journal, and all versions before that had a bug
in processing that.

Remove the somewhat pointless screen following journalctl commands. We
really don't want or need those, and they tend to build up over time.

Depends-On: I24513f5cbac2c34cf0130bf812ff2df6ad76657c

Change-Id: I6af6d1857effaf662a9d72bd394864934eacbe70

commit_message:
Handle shade and glean in DEVSTACK_PROJECT_FROM_GIT

Shade and glean are in openstack-infra, not openstack, so special case
them when adding to PROJECTS variable.

Needed-By: I27ce27f54e78abc71d4329eb97415ef5dc6e4db3
Change-Id: I1a6fb66e25301c6e7f85cf81cf5259192276c437

commit_message:
Use compat names for journal files

This uses compatibility names for journal files, which means less
changes in the log processing.

It also captures a relevant slice of the journal for local inspection.

Change-Id: I24513f5cbac2c34cf0130bf812ff2df6ad76657c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/47/460947/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copy over any devstack systemd unit journals. Note, we will no # longer get separate new/old grenade logs when this happens. local jremote="" if uses_debs; then if ! dpkg -s "systemd-journal-remote" > /dev/null; then apt_get_install systemd-journal-remote fi jremote="/lib/systemd/systemd-journal-remote" elif is_fedora; then if ! rpm --quiet -q "systemd-journal-gateway"; then sudo yum install -y systemd-journal-gateway fi jremote="/usr/lib/systemd/systemd-journal-remote" fi local name="" name=$(echo $u | sed 's/devstack@/screen-/' | sed 's/\.service//') sudo journalctl -o short-precise --unit $u | sudo tee $BASE/logs/$name.txt > /dev/null # export the journal in native format to make it downloadable # for later searching, makes a class of debugging much easier. sudo journalctl -o export --unit "devstack@*-*" | \ $jremote -o $BASE/logs/devstack.journal -
deleted_lines: # Copy over any devstack systemd unit journals sudo journalctl -o short-precise --unit $u | sudo tee $BASE/logs/$u.log.txt > /dev/null

commit_message:
Enable monasca transform functional tests

Invoke functional tests as part of
devstack gate testing for monasca
transform.

Depends-on: I6a0a9d7067e991617fb645e4d68598522c1b95af

Change-Id: Ic9cc348e944c9c72916f81d14ed79b9bdf034c52
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-transform refs/changes/79/460379/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash -xe # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # This script is executed inside post_test_hook function in devstack gate. function generate_testr_results { if [ -f .testrepository/0 ]; then sudo .tox/functional/bin/testr last --subunit > $WORKSPACE/testrepository.subunit sudo mv $WORKSPACE/testrepository.subunit $BASE/logs/testrepository.subunit sudo /usr/os-testr-env/bin/subunit2html $BASE/logs/testrepository.subunit $BASE/logs/testr_results.html sudo gzip -9 $BASE/logs/testrepository.subunit sudo gzip -9 $BASE/logs/testr_results.html sudo chown jenkins:jenkins $BASE/logs/testrepository.subunit.gz $BASE/logs/testr_results.html.gz sudo chmod a+r $BASE/logs/testrepository.subunit.gz $BASE/logs/testr_results.html.gz fi } export MONASCA_TRANSFORM_DIR="$BASE/new/monasca-transform" # Go to the monasca-transform dir cd $MONASCA_TRANSFORM_DIR if [[ -z "$STACK_USER" ]]; then export STACK_USER=stack fi sudo chown -R $STACK_USER:stack $MONASCA_TRANSFORM_DIR # Run tests echo "Running monasca-transform functional test suite" set +e sudo -E -H -u ${STACK_USER:-${USER}} tox -efunctional EXIT_CODE=$? set -e # Collect and parse result generate_testr_results exit $EXIT_CODE

    trove-datastore-database: used to set datastore_registry_ext in
        trove-guestagent.conf
    trove-database-volume-support: corresponds to volume_support per DB in
        trove.conf
    default-neutron-networks: same name as in trove.conf

Add Newton version of the trove configuration files, remove verbose
setting as it's deprecated and ignored in Newton.

Change-Id: I0a9a33128e13ad232f28996b24fea48d081786f2
"}]
commit_message:
Maintainability and config updates.

Use default openstack charm hooks where possible, implemented
2 functions to facilitate this: get_amqp_credentials() and get_database_setup().

Allow for additional trove configuration by the user:
    trove-volume-support: same name as in trove.conf
    trove-datastore-database: used to set datastore_registry_ext in
        trove-guestagent.conf
    trove-database-volume-support: corresponds to volume_support per DB in
        trove.conf
    default-neutron-networks: same name as in trove.conf

Add Newton version of the trove configuration files, remove verbose
setting as it's deprecated and ignored in Newton.

Change-Id: I0a9a33128e13ad232f28996b24fea48d081786f2

commit_message:
Use gem-based puppet syntax jobs for infra

Since we removed puppet from the nodepool nodes, the puppet parser
validate command in the puppet-syntax job fails since puppet is not
installed. Rather than modifying that job to install puppet, we can
re-use the existing 'rake syntax' job that the puppet-openstack group
has defined for their modules, which installs puppet via gems and is
therefore simpler. We can also now remove the plain puppet-syntax job
since nothing is using it.

Change-Id: I082ea72743634b8ce0106786ab4ec35add874c8d

commit_message:
Deploy openstack-nova-migration during upgrade process

openstack-nova-migration package was added in Ocata. We need to deploy
the package during the upgrade process otherwise the tool won't be
available after an upgrade.

Change-Id: Ia53e862958f2744fd0fcd420b2bb8a3f24d12431
Closes-Bug: #1687081

commit_message:
WIP: Explore functional test for the resource tracker

That main purpose of this is to provide some functional testing for
the resource tracker when used with the placement api. It takes
advantage of the PlacementFixture to ensure that the API is there.

The current test does a simple inventory and allocation (with one
instance) test.

The hope is that this can be used as the basis for handling the more
complex situation involved when working with Ironic.

Change-Id: If075b9e71ccd31de81b3503dc77b289f008f53de
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/09/427309/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock from oslo_config import cfg from nova.compute import vm_states from nova import context from nova import objects from nova import test from nova.tests import fixtures from nova.tests import uuidsentinel as uuids CONF = cfg.CONF class ResourceTrackerTestCase(test.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(ResourceTrackerTestCase, self).setUp() self.flags(debug=True) self.useFixture(fixtures.PlacementFixture()) self.compute = self.start_service('compute') self.context = context.RequestContext('fake', 'fake') self.resource_tracker = self.compute._get_resource_tracker() scheduler_client = self.resource_tracker.scheduler_client self.report_client = scheduler_client.reportclient @mock.patch('nova.compute.utils.is_volume_backed_instance', return_value=False) @mock.patch('nova.compute.stats.Stats.update_stats_for_instance') def test_resource_tracker_updates_for_fake_mini(self, mock_stats, mock_vbi): nodename = 'fake-mini' instance_vcpu = 1 compute_node = self.resource_tracker.compute_nodes[nodename] # Confirm resource provider resource_provider = self.report_client._get_resource_provider( compute_node.uuid) self.assertEqual(nodename, resource_provider.name) self.assertEqual(compute_node.uuid, resource_provider.uuid) # Confirm inventory inventory = self.report_client._get_inventory(compute_node.uuid) vcpu_inventory = inventory['inventories']['VCPU'] self.assertEqual(compute_node.vcpus, vcpu_inventory['total']) # Confirm no allocations for this provider allocations = self.report_client._get_allocations(compute_node.uuid) self.assertEqual({}, allocations) # Pretend we've got an instance, we need a flavor for # calculations to happens as expected. flavor = objects.Flavor( id=1, name='flavor1', memory_mb=256, vcpus=instance_vcpu, root_gb=1, ephemeral_gb=1, flavorid='1', swap=0, rxtx_factor=1.0, vcpu_weight=1, disabled=False, is_public=True, extra_specs={}, projects=[]) instance = objects.Instance(self.context, vcpus=instance_vcpu, flavor=flavor, memory_mb=256, root_gb=1, ephemeral_gb=0, project_id='fake', uuid=uuids.instance) instance.vm_state = vm_states.ACTIVE self.resource_tracker.tracked_instances[instance.uuid] = instance self.resource_tracker._update_usage_from_instances( self.context, [instance], nodename) # We should see some allocations now for this resource # provider. allocations = self.report_client._get_allocations(compute_node.uuid) instance_allocations = allocations[uuids.instance]['resources'] self.assertEqual(instance_vcpu, instance_allocations['VCPU'])

commit_message:
Release neutron-lib 1.6.0

Change Ic455e1af2796e58025381160dc5c3b83217413fa recently landed in
neutron-lib which rehomes an integral part of our API efforts. We'd like
a new release of lib ASAP so that we can consume the change(s) early-on
in the release cycle to reduce tail-end risk involved with that
transition.

In addition I9966c90e3f90552b41ed84a68b19f3e540426432 is included in
this release and is required to finish up our neutron-lib callback
efforts.

Change-Id: I7f3d4d7451930fcc1d66b331ddc53d24cb86666a

commit_message:
Remove fedora and debian from puppet-apply jobs

The only puppet-apply test that was being run for these OS types was the
dummy single-use-slave-devstack node, which now does nothing. In order
to remove the dummy node from site.pp we need to stop trying to run
tests on these OS's, otherwise the apply test will fail due to being
unable to find a puppet node to run tests for.

Change-Id: Ib1c2f6085f9e8b40e6a78cfb898738b0950bc339

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/59/461359/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Tree-Like vs. Complete Digraph Configuration ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ The configuration is specified as a digraph_. Each module is a node; a edge is the relation of the current element to its `base`. Because the general digraph_ approach is somewhat complex when it comes to write it down, the configuration can also be given as a tree_. .. _digraph: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Directed_graph .. _tree: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tree_(graph_theory) Example: The tree like notation .. code-block:: yaml mkfs: name: root_fs base: root_part mount: mount_point: / is exactly the same as writing .. code-block:: yaml mkfs: name: root_fs base: root_part mount: name: mount_root_fs base: root_fs mount_point: / Non existing `name` and `base` entries in the tree notation are automatically generated: the `name` is the name of the base module prepended by the type-name of the module itself; the `base` element is automatically set to the parent node in the tree. In mostly all cases the much simpler tree notation can be used. Nevertheless there are some use cases when the more general digraph notation is needed. Example: when there is the need to combine two or more modules into one new, like combining a couple of physical volumes into one volume group. Tree and digraph notations can be mixed as needed in a configuration.

commit_message:
WIP: Add devmode-ovb script

This script uses the current tripleo-environments
settings as a first cut. The aim is to move these
settings to a public repo.

Running devmode-ovb requires a user to pass a
credentials file for an active tenant on a host
cloud where the OVB stack will be deployed.

The script does not clean up the stack deployed.
In jobs this is done in a separate step.

Change-Id: Icca66aa5f175add8d0a021d50d9d91f2e2458b5f
Depends-On: I3b182e72329c9a724d237c204741f10979596259
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/81/444481/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash : ${GATE:=1} : ${WORKSPACE:=$HOME/.quickstart} : ${RELEASE:=master-tripleo-ci} : ${CONFIG:=ovb_net_iso_minimal_pacemaker_config.yml} : ${BUILD_SYS:=delorean} : ${HOST_CLOUD:=rdocloud} : ${NETWORK_ISOLATION:=public-bond} : ${RC_FILE:} interactive=0 reproducer_type=gerrit usage () { echo "Usage: $0 [options] virthost" echo "" echo "Options:" echo " -c, --config <type>" echo " specify the node configuration (default=$CONFIG)" echo " -i, --network-isolation <type>" echo " specify the network isolation type for deployment" echo " (default=$NETWORK_ISOLATION)" echo " -l, --host-cloud <name>" echo " specify the host cloud on which to deploy the OVB stack" echo " (default=$HOST_CLOUD)" echo " -n, --no-gate do not ask for gating a commit when gating" echo " variables are missing (default is gating)" echo " -r, --rc-file <path>" echo " specify full path to rc file with tenant credentials" echo " -w, --working-dir <dir>" echo " directory where the virtualenv, inventory files, etc." echo " are created (default=$WORKSPACE)" echo " -h, --help print this help and exit" echo " virthost target machine used for deployment, required argument" } zuul-gate () { if [[ -z "$ZUUL_HOST" ]]; then interactive=1 echo "Which Zuul host to use? (default=review.openstack.org)" read -p "ZUUL_HOST=" ZUUL_HOST ZUUL_HOST=${ZUUL_HOST:-"review.openstack.org"} echo "" fi ZUUL_HOST=${ZUUL_HOST:-"review.openstack.org"} if [[ -z "$ZUUL_CHANGES" ]]; then interactive=1 echo "Specify ZUUL_CHANGES variable from logs/reproduce.sh" read -p "ZUUL_CHANGES=" ZUUL_CHANGES echo "" fi export ZUUL_{HOST,CHANGES} } gerrit-gate () { if [[ -z "$GERRIT_HOST" ]]; then interactive=1 echo "Which Gerrit host to use? (default=review.openstack.org)" read -p "GERRIT_HOST=" GERRIT_HOST GERRIT_HOST=${GERRIT_HOST:-"review.openstack.org"} echo "" fi if [[ -z "$GERRIT_BRANCH" ]]; then interactive=1 echo "Which branch is the patch on? (default=master)" read -p "GERRIT_BRANCH=" GERRIT_BRANCH GERRIT_BRANCH=${GERRIT_BRANCH:-master} echo "" fi if [[ -z "$GERRIT_CHANGE_ID" ]]; then interactive=1 echo "What is the Change-Id? Can be found in the commit message." echo "Note: all \"Depends-On:\" changes are going to be built as well." read -p "GERRIT_CHANGE_ID=" GERRIT_CHANGE_ID echo "" fi if [[ -z "$GERRIT_PATCHSET_REVISION" ]]; then interactive=1 echo "What is the git commit hash of the patchset?" echo "It can be found in the Commit field on Gerrit" read -p "GERRIT_PATCHSET_REVISION=" GERRIT_PATCHSET_REVISION echo "" fi export GERRIT_{HOST,BRANCH,CHANGE_ID,PATCHSET_REVISION} } interactive-gate () { if [[ -n "$ZUUL_HOST" ]]; then reproducer_type=zuul fi if [[ -z "$ZUUL_HOST" && -z "$GERRIT_HOST" ]]; then interactive=1 echo "Do you want to reproduce an environment from an upstream CI Zuul job" echo "or use a Gerrit change? (default=gerrit)" read -p "[zuul/GERRIT] " reproducer_type echo "" fi if [[ $reproducer_type = 'zuul' ]]; then zuul-gate else gerrit-gate fi if [[ "$interactive" = "1" ]]; then echo "Check if these values are correct:" else echo "Running with the following variables:" fi echo "" if [[ $reproducer_type = 'zuul' ]]; then echo "ZUUL_HOST=$ZUUL_HOST" echo "ZUUL_CHANGES=$ZUUL_CHANGES" echo "export ZUUL_{HOST,CHANGES}" else echo "GERRIT_HOST=$GERRIT_HOST" echo "GERRIT_BRANCH=$GERRIT_BRANCH" echo "GERRIT_CHANGE_ID=$GERRIT_CHANGE_ID" echo "GERRIT_PATCHSET_REVISION=$GERRIT_PATCHSET_REVISION" echo "export GERRIT_{HOST,BRANCH,CHANGE_ID,PATCHSET_REVISION}" fi echo "" if [[ "$interactive" = "1" ]]; then echo "Note: You can re-run this script non-interactively by pasting" echo "the lines above to the console before rerunning the script." echo "Hit ENTER to continue, or CTRL-C to exit" read fi } while [ "x$1" != "x" ]; do case "$1" in --working-dir|-w) WORKSPACE=$(realpath $2) shift ;; --config|-c) CONFIG=$2 shift ;; --network-isolation|-i) NETWORK_ISOLATION=$2 shift ;; --host-cloud|-l) HOST_CLOUD=$2 shift ;; --no-gate|-n) GATE=0 ;; --rc-file|-r) RC_FILE=$2 shift ;; --help|-h) usage exit ;; --) shift break ;; -*) echo "ERROR: unknown option: $1" >&2 usage >&2 exit 2 ;; *) break ;; esac shift done pushd $(dirname ${BASH_SOURCE[0]:-$0}) # variables needed for the CI script export VIRTHOST=$1 export WORKSPACE export HW_ENV_DIR=tripleo-environments/hardware_environments/ovb_host_cloud export OVB_SETTINGS_FILE=$WORKSPACE/tripleo-environments/provisioners/heat/ovb_common.yml export OVB_CREDS_FILE=$WORKSPACE/tripleo-environments/provisioners/heat/environments/{$HOST_CLOUD}.yml export PLAYBOOK=baremetal-full-deploy.yml if [[ -z $VIRTHOST ]]; then usage echo "" echo "Specify the virthost to use. You need to be able to ssh as root without" echo "password with your current user (i.e. ssh root@\$VIRTHOST must succeed)" exit 1 fi if [[ -z $RC_FILE ]]; then usage echo "" echo "Specify the rc tenant file to use." echo "You need to have access to a tenant on the host cloud." exit 1 fi if [ "$GATE" = "1" ]; then interactive-gate JOB_TYPE=dlrn-gate else JOB_TYPE=periodic fi source $RC_FILE bash ci-scripts/full-deploy-ovb.sh \ $RELEASE \ $HW_ENV_DIR \ $NETWORK_ISOLATION \ $CONFIG \ $OVB_SETTINGS_FILE \ $OVB_CREDS_FILE \ $PLAYBOOK \ $JOB_TYPE \ $VIRTHOST popd

commit_message:
Raise gabbi to >= 1.30.0

Some projects (aodh, ceilometer, gnocchi) use the HISTORY features of
gabbi that requires 1.30. So bump the requirements to ensure gabbi
version have this feature.

http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=%5C%24HISTORY&i=nope&files=.*%2F.*yaml&repos=

Change-Id: I8bbc015f333b8966c906048eda0b72c58139566d

commit_message:
Add direction to known bandwidth_limit_rules parameters

Parameter `direction` is introduced for qos_bandwidth_limit
rule type in neutron in Ia13568879c2b6f80fb190ccafe7e19ca05b0c6a8
By default each rule has got EGRESS direction so this value of
direction is supported by existing qos_driver.

Change-Id: I6bfc15aa6473586534b155b9d0c24f36e2af9685
Depends-On: Ia13568879c2b6f80fb190ccafe7e19ca05b0c6a8
Related-Bug: #1586056
Related-Bug: #1560961
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/37/460737/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.common import constants as n_constsSUPPORTED_RULES = { qos_consts.RULE_TYPE_BANDWIDTH_LIMIT: { qos_consts.MAX_KBPS: { 'type:range': [0, n_consts.DB_INTEGER_MAX_VALUE]}, qos_consts.MAX_BURST: { 'type:range': [0, n_consts.DB_INTEGER_MAX_VALUE]}, qos_consts.DIRECTION: { 'type:values': [n_consts.EGRESS_DIRECTION]} }, }

commit_message:
Remove subunit-trace fork

This makes tox use the latest version of the tool from os-testr repo,
which contains some valuable changes, like the one making the gate fail
if for some reason no tests are executed because all of them are
skipped.

Conflicts:
      tox.ini
      tools/subunit-trace.py

Change-Id: If88be4b310d746ccc885e3d0c1db8a4dfabb2a28
(cherry picked from commit a490cdd037e4288ffe829a0a5082bbc06173a4ba)
(cherry picked from commit 58031f5224ac0499953beba12ebd4a55650b0cc9)

commit_message:
Remove subunit-trace fork

This makes tox use the latest version of the tool from os-testr repo,
which contains some valuable changes, like the one making the gate fail
if for some reason no tests are executed because all of them are
skipped.

Conflicts:
      tox.ini

Change-Id: If88be4b310d746ccc885e3d0c1db8a4dfabb2a28
(cherry picked from commit a490cdd037e4288ffe829a0a5082bbc06173a4ba)

commit_message:
Add net-info macro to puppet jobs

This adds extra debug information about DIB images and networking
setup to console logs.  Helpfully when you want to troubleshoot a job.

Change-Id: I4e3838bd160dd6f10b0ef27970fa32e59df21050
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-28 07:19:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-net-config/commit/8aac37f3845ab2f9cf2c63dce0b75d6765a70c49', 'message': 'Adding Support for Jumbo frames

The feature Jumbo Frames[2] can be enabled by configuring the MTU
value for the OVS-DPDK interface and OVS-DPDK bond. Already os-net-config
supports an option for providing MTU values[1], but for DPDK it has to be
set to the OvS DB with below command:
ovs-vsctl -- set Interface <DPDK device> mtu_request=<frame size>

This patch enables the above.

commit_message:
Configure mtu value for DPDK port

MTU value is already written to ifcfg file if provided on the interface,
but for dpdk port, we have to apply this to ovs-vsctl command via ovs_extra.
This patch is adding the support to configure the given mtu vlaue to the
dpdk port using ovs_extra.

implements: blueprint ovs-2-6-features-dpdk

Change-Id: Ic01ed8cee2edbd648de0b64dc7f01da80c153d81

commit_message:
Defer calls to tripleoclient.object_store

With a recent osc-lib[1] change it is no longer possible to make
auth-requiring calls in the command __init__.

This change defers calls to tripleoclient.object_store so that it is
made when auth is properly setup.

[1] I72ae6154268bdf26be6054c0fef6a4c67c71119c
Closes-Bug: #1687032

Change-Id: If640da00d9b8d49ff935209e3b31dcf0f327ad63
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/36/461336/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Adjust fog-core pin

The xmlrpc requirement was adjusted in later versions of fog-core
https://github.com/fog/fog-core/issues/206

So let's uncap it but just exclude 1.44.0.

Change-Id: Ieac62a87ebcb48b86392a9073c2df3ebd7f6eb3e

commit_message:
Support TOTP credential

Support credential type 'totp'. In addition, introduce an option to
generate provisioning uri where users can use to provision their
mobile device via the QR barcode method.

Users also have an option to specify an already base32-encoded
credential. This is useful in a situation where one needs to import
a credential that has already been provisioned elsewhere.

Change-Id: I7e4f773f381e62c1a6af419634469095cbbe02be
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/54/279854/15 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import base64from openstackclient.common import exceptions choices=['ec2', 'cert', 'totp'], '--include-google-authenticator-provisioning-url', action='store_true', help='This option is applicable to "totp" credentials only. If specify, it will return the Google Authenticator QC code provisioning uri.', ) parser.add_argument( # FIXME(gyee): this stuff probably need to be in python-keystoneclient as # they are being shared here and in Keystone totp auth plugin. Ideally, we # should enhance Keystone V3 credential APIs to support provisioning. # Meaning, if blob is absent and depending on credential type, server # should generate one on behave of the user and return it in the response. # The benefit of server-side provisioning is that the credential # requirements are controlled by the deployer. Requirements such as # credential size, credential expiration, credential activation, etc are # all controlled by the deployer, in accordance with whateve compliance # they need to abide by. def _generate_provisioning_url(self, user_id, secret_key): # FIXME(gyee): import them on-demand for now as they are only needed by # totp credentials and Google Authenticator provisioning uri generation from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.hashes import SHA1 from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.twofactor.totp import TOTP # NOTE(gyee): Google Authenticator uses 6 digits. And for TOTP, we use # the standard 30 second time step. totp = TOTP(secret_key, 6, SHA1(), 30, backend=default_backend()) # NOTE(gyee): use user_id as account name as it is unique and Keystone # as the issuer because this credential is to be used for Keystone # authentication only. totp_uri = totp.get_provisioning_uri(user_id, 'Keystone') # now need to to encode it as it is part of Google url to pick up the # QC code google_qc_url_prefix = ('https://www.google.com/chart?chs=200x200&' + 'chld=M|0&cht=qr&chl=') return google_qc_url_prefix + six.moves.urllib.parse.quote(totp_uri) provisioning_url = None blob = parsed_args.data if parsed_args.type.lower() == 'totp': if len(blob) < 16: # NOTE(gyee): according to # # https://cryptography.io/en/latest # # TOTP credential/secret key must be at least 128-bits msg = ('TOTP credentials must be at least 128-bit (16 bytes)') raise exceptions.CommandError(msg) if parsed_args.include_google_authenticator_provisioning_url: provisioning_url = self._generate_provisioning_url( user_id, parsed_args.data) # FIXME(gyee): totp credentials should be base32 encoded. We # probably need another parameter to support already encoded # blob so we are not restricted to printable characters only. blob = base64.b32encode(blob) blob=blob, if provisioning_url: credential._info['provisioning_url'] = provisioning_url

commit_message:
Make sure Cinder and SSL can live happily ever after

Cinder can only support SSL when running with either Apache mod_wsgi
or TLS proxy. Cinder + eventlet does not support SSL. Furthermore,
when SSL is enabled for Cinder, it is also applicable to Cinder API
service. In other words, 'is_ssl_enabled_service cinder' implies
'is_ssl_enabled_service c-api'.

SSL is enabled for Cinder only under the following conditions:

 1. both USE_SSL=True and CINDER_USE_MOD_WSGI=True
 2. tls-proxy service is enabled

Change-Id: I295d3a7d180018048c854af53da66ee46f4f4052
Closes-Bug: 1533813

deleted_lines: if is_ssl_enabled_service "cinder" || is_service_enabled tls-proxy; then# Toggle for deploying Cinder under HTTPD + mod_wsgi CINDER_USE_MOD_WSGI=${CINDER_USE_MOD_WSGI:-False} if is_ssl_enabled_service c-api; then # Register SSL certificates if provided if is_ssl_enabled_service cinder; then ensure_certificates CINDER iniset $CINDER_CONF DEFAULT ssl_cert_file "$CINDER_SSL_CERT" iniset $CINDER_CONF DEFAULT ssl_key_file "$CINDER_SSL_KEY" fi if is_ssl_enabled_service "c-api"; then

commit_message:
Add RBAC test for force-deleting a backup

This patch adds a new test for force-deleting a backup in
test_volumes_backup_rbac, which tests the cinder policy action:
"volume_extension:backup_admin_actions:force_delete".

This patch also corrects the currently wrong policy action for
the test test_snapshot_force_delete from
"volume_extension:volume_admin_actions:force_delete" to
"volume_extension:snapshot_admin_actions:force_delete". (The
``_force_delete`` function in the cinder admin actions API enforces
the policy action corresponding to the resource name [0][1]).

[0] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/api/contrib/admin_actions.py#L133
[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/api/contrib/admin_actions.py#L82

Change-Id: Icecf2152fe84da2847ae677a74a4d183eb4cd88b

commit_message:
Add direction to known bandwidth_limit_rules parameters

Parameter `direction` is introduced for qos_bandwidth_limit
rule type in neutron in Ia13568879c2b6f80fb190ccafe7e19ca05b0c6a8
By default each rule has got EGRESS direction so this value of
direction is supported by existing qos_driver.

Depends-On: Ia13568879c2b6f80fb190ccafe7e19ca05b0c6a8

Change-Id: I6bfc15aa6473586534b155b9d0c24f36e2af9685
Related-Bug: #1586056
Related-Bug: #1560961

commit_message:
adds voting os-vif jobs

- This change introduces a gate pipeline for os-vif.
- This change moves
  gate-tempest-dsvm-nova-os-vif-ubuntu-xenial-nv
  and
  gate-tempest-dsvm-nova-os-vif-linuxbridge-ubuntu-xenial-nv
  to voting jobs in the check and gate pipeline for os-vif.

Change-Id: I1afbd0f3e363469ae29d749a778775bf1b50aed8

commit_message:
neutron-lib incubating periodic hacking checks

As per the discussion in [1], we need a neutron-lib
periodic job that can run neutron-lib "incubating"
hacking checks. The goal of this job is to inform
consumers of upcoming checks and allow them time
to adopt the upcoming checks. As such the periodic
job should be run as non-voting; failures can be easily
flagged, but don't inhibit workflow.

This patch introduces a periodic job that's part of the
periodic-python-jobs-with-neutron-lib-master job group
to carry out that goal.

Specifically:
- A new helper script is defined to carry out the execution.
This script must update the [hacking] section of tox.ini
to use a said local-check-factory.
- A corresponding job template that's added to the neutron-lib
master job group. This job is non-voting as noted above.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/350723/

commit_message:
Remove nova-cert

This commit removes nova-cert which has been deprecated since change
Id7a1fc943cbe6d860a50d3cc776717b55351004b. The APIs have been hard coded
to return a 410 whenever they're called now. For the API ref a new
section for obsolete apis is added to the bottom of the page and the
certificates api ref is moved there.

Implements bp remove-nova-cert

Change-Id: I2c78a0c6599b92040146cf9f0042cff8fd2509c3

"""Starter script for Nova Cert.""" import sys from oslo_log import log as logging from oslo_log import versionutils from oslo_reports import guru_meditation_report as gmr import nova.conf from nova import config from nova.i18n import _LW from nova import objects from nova import service from nova import utils from nova import version CONF = nova.conf.CONF def main(): config.parse_args(sys.argv) logging.setup(CONF, "nova") utils.monkey_patch() objects.register_all() log = logging.getLogger(__name__) versionutils.report_deprecated_feature( log, _LW('The nova-cert service is deprecated and will be removed ' 'in a future release.')) gmr.TextGuruMeditation.setup_autorun(version) server = service.Service.create(binary='nova-cert') service.serve(server) service.wait()

commit_message:
Port unversioned Version resources to resource2

Most services have a Version resource in their unversioned namespace,
generally predating the proxy interface. As such none of them are being
exposed or used as of right now, but rather than remove them we should
port them over as-is, then later figure out if we need to expose them
for use or if we don't actually need them.

Change-Id: I8f4ed67f6185bd1928ce73f8059d629dc0952f6b

deleted_lines: from openstack import resource links = resource.prop('links') status = resource.prop('status')

commit_message:
Port metric v1 to resource2

This change ports metric v1 to resource2. Note that most of this stuff
isn't exposed in the proxy, but that change should be made elsewhere. I
also removed the resource.Generic.create method as that doesn't seem
necessary based on what's documented.

Change-Id: I662ad4811ff84bd7b7726d02d676e9f5f05e3808

Replace generic api_extensions checks

that is being called in each test file.

commit_message:
Extends driver-list, driver-show supporting new hardware types

- Extend the driver-list command with --type argument, which, if supplied,
limits the driver list to only classic drivers (classic value) or
hardware types (dynamic value), and --detail to show detailed info
of drivers.

- Extend the output of the driver-show command with more info of driver.

Change-Id: I5f72c47805ae9f761250f500098bfef4d502e419
Partial-Bug: #1524745

commit_message:
Fix max_over_subscription_ratio precedence

Cinder should use max_over_subscription_ratio if
lvm_max_over_subscription_ratio is not set.

Change-Id: Iebb069e17a6f8a2cb9b5ae75004c9471cbb1cc65
Closes-Bug: #1602235

commit_message:
Add RBAC tests for cinder os-quota-class-sets API

This patch adds RBAC tests for the cinder os-quota-class-sets API,
which cover the policy action "volume_extension:quota_classes" [0][1].

[0] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/api/contrib/quota_classes.py#L44
[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/api/contrib/quota_classes.py#L55

Change-Id: Iba5dc5caf7ed3f1ad344b0d7b2d6c13a9842cf79
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/patrole refs/changes/47/461247/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - | Add RBAC tests for cinder os-quota-class-sets API, which cover the policy action "volume_extension:quota_classes".

commit_message:
Adds missing volumes client tests

Adds missing volumes client tests for set bootable, reserve,
unreserve, and update metadata actions, as well as renames update
metadata item and delete metadata items tests to properly represent
what actions they perform.

Change-Id: I75bbf62635f3476e658f5b162f5bd65f9fcaab08
Implements: bp: test-volumes-rbac

commit_message:
WIP qpid-dispatch-router mesh

Change-Id: I65fff3c053a2d4c2dbd0a276e72601f36a9d1504
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo refs/changes/35/459835/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*qdr_node_names*] # Set of nodes for qdr mesh deployment setup # Defaults to hiera('rabbitmq_node_names') # $qdr_node_names = pick(hiera('qdr_node_names',undef),hiera('rabbitmq_node_names')), # NB: puppet 4.8 introduces break(), which is better than this mess $connectors = $qdr_node_names.reduce([]) |$memo, $node| { if $::hostname in $node { $memo + true } else { if true in $memo { $memo } else { $memo + [{'host' => $node, 'role' => 'inter-router', 'port' => '25672'}] } } } - true $router_mode = size($qdr_node_names) ? { 1 => 'standalone', default => 'interior', } $extra_listeners = size($qdr_node_names) ? { 1 => [], default => [{'host' => '0.0.0.0', 'port' => '25672', 'role' => 'inter-router'}], } $extra_addresses = [{'prefix' => 'openstack.org/om/rpc/multicast', 'distribution' => 'multicast'}, {'prefix' => 'openstack.org/om/rpc/unicast', 'distribution' => 'closest'}, {'prefix' => 'openstack.org/om/rpc/anycast', 'distribution' => 'balanced'}, {'prefix' => 'openstack.org/om/notify/multicast', 'distribution' => 'multicast'},{'prefix' => 'openstack.org/om/notify/unicast', 'distribution' => 'closest'}, {'prefix' => 'openstack.org/om/notify/anycast','distribution' => 'balanced'}] class { '::qdr': listener_addr => '0.0.0.0', listener_port => "${qdr_listener_port}", router_mode => $router_mode, connectors => $connectors, extra_listeners => $extra_listeners, extra_addresses => $extra_addresses, }

commit_message:
Add options for selecting zones for live migration

This patch adds following two configuration options in
the [compute] group:
- live_migration_src_availability_zone
- live_migration_dest_availability_zone

When they're non-empty, live migration tests will use hosts
from these availability zones.

Change-Id: I4ef08df2b634fc995647ca5caf0ade9b1f312595
Closes-Bug: #1626101
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/76/419776/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.StrOpt('live_migration_src_availability_zone', default='', help="The availability zone of the source host for live " "migration. Leave empty if it doesn't matter."), cfg.StrOpt('live_migration_dest_availability_zone', default='', help="The availability zone of the destination host for live " "migration. Leave empty if it doesn't matter."),

commit_message:
Change auth_strategy default to keystone

The current default for auth_strategy is noauth, which is not how it is
expected to be set in production environments.

Note: Functional tests should be good with noauth.

Co-Authored-By: Adam Harwell <flux.adam@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Michael Johnson <johnsomor@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Refactor block_device: isolate the getval call

Add a new getval call that allows to retrieve values
from the block device. Also isolating the block device
information into a 'blockdev' dictionary entry, to better
return it with the getval command.

This is a refactor from the original code at
I3600c6a3d663c697b59d91bd3fbb5e408af345e4.

Change-Id: I93d33669a3a0ae644eab9f9b955bb5a9470cadeb
Co-Authored-By: Andreas Florath <andreas@florath.net>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/46/461346/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cmd_init: initialized the block device level config. After this call it is possible to e.g. query information from the (partially automatic generated) internal state like root-label. cmd_getval: retrieve information about the (internal) block device state like the block image device (for bootloader) or the root-label (for writing fstab). def cmd_init(self): """Initialize block device setup This initializes the block device setup layer. One major task is to parse and check the configuration, write it down for later examiniation and execution. """ with open(self.params['config'], "rt") as config_fd: self.config = yaml.safe_load(config_fd) logger.debug("Config before merge [%s]" % self.config) self._merge_into_config() logger.debug("Final config [%s]" % self.config) # Write the final config with open(self.config_json_file_name, "wt") as fd: json.dump(self.config, fd) logger.info("Wrote final block device config to [%s]" % self.config_json_file_name) def cmd_getval(self): """Retrieve value from block device level This is needed for backward compatibility (non python) access to (internal) configuration. """ symbol = self.args.symbol logger.info("Getting value for [%s]" % symbol) if symbol == 'image-block-partition': # If there is no partition needed, pass back directly the # image. if 'root' in self.state['blockdev']: print("%s" % self.state['blockdev']['root']['device']) else: print("%s" % self.state['blockdev']['image0']['device']) return 0 if symbol == 'image-path': print("%s" % self.state['blockdev']['image0']['image']) return 0 logger.error("Invalid symbol [%s] for getval" % symbol) return 1

commit_message:
Remove subunit-trace fork

This makes tox use the latest version of the tool from os-testr repo,
which contains some valuable changes, like the one making the gate fail
if for some reason no tests are executed because all of them are
skipped.

Conflicts:
      tox.ini

Change-Id: If88be4b310d746ccc885e3d0c1db8a4dfabb2a28
(cherry picked from commit b22b4a3d976134b112bf901bf3cc27afd3ae9879)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/12/457412/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: #!/usr/bin/env bash TESTRARGS=$1 exec 3>&1 status=$(exec 4>&1 >&3; ( python setup.py testr --slowest --testr-args="--subunit $TESTRARGS"; echo $? >&4 ) | $(dirname $0)/subunit-trace.py -f) && exit $status

commit_message:
Remove subunit-trace fork

This makes tox use the latest version of the tool from os-testr repo,
which contains some valuable changes, like the one making the gate fail
if for some reason no tests are executed because all of them are
skipped.

Change-Id: If88be4b310d746ccc885e3d0c1db8a4dfabb2a28
(cherry picked from commit b22b4a3d976134b112bf901bf3cc27afd3ae9879)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/11/457411/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: #!/usr/bin/env bash TESTRARGS=$1 exec 3>&1 status=$(exec 4>&1 >&3; ( python setup.py testr --slowest --testr-args="--subunit $TESTRARGS"; echo $? >&4 ) | $(dirname $0)/subunit-trace.py -f) && exit $status

commit_message:
manila: mark python-manilaclient to clone from git

Manila tests require the manilaclient from master, there for the
manilaclient is cloned in the manila devstack plugin.
Some projects (such as Fuxi, Karbor) depend on manila, and would
like to install the packaged manilaclient.
Align with other python clients - mark it to be cloned from git, and
in the devstack plugin clone it only if it has been marked.

Needed-By: Ia8e726b9358f6901c172a31f638a59eba523e0fa
Change-Id: I94d2f143159b60c4f8693e35fe844bc1e411e580

commit_message:
Use https for docs.openstack.org (7/7)

We switched to https for docs.openstack.org, adjust URLs.

This handle _independent deliverables.

Note this does not include fairy-slipper and puppet, touching those
files creates errors because fairy-slipper is retired and puppet files
fail building liberty docs.

Change-Id: Ibc521ac37df40bb53310aa0cf00f5a710b5f4cb1

commit_message:
cleanup: remove unused clone of system-config

system-config was cloned twice in order to not interfere with
slave repo cache during image creation.
This clone is not used anymore and can be eliminated

Change-Id: I0ff0675ead5f4c192c863f6b0be84f3364f84c0a

commit_message:
MariaDB: Reduce size of default PVC

This PS reduces the default size of the PVC to one that works on systems
with limited storage avalible. It has no effect on the resilance or
production readyness status of the deployed cluster, simply the amount
of data that can be stored within it.

Change-Id: Ic01b9a6658a1b4161b160f35842060ad84cb8ec7

commit_message:
Stop installing and running puppet in node builds

Move non-puppet-related parts of the puppet element into other elements,
remove the puppet element, and stop running the prepare-node script.

\o/

Change-Id: Ib241ea976ca0a3d661599f36e3f5a2d4eb023c08

subject: tests: fix tests for functional tests without dsvm
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-24 06:38:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer/commit/5d8b4a78f0e7ec49f8cf2b115f370f58f27714d2', 'message': "tests: fix tests for functional tests without dsvm

Currently functional tests pass in gate just because some calls are
done on real devstack, and passed by chance. We don't need dsvm at all
with pifpaf.

This change fixes this tests and add bindep.txt file for new gate jobs
without dsvm will be setup to ensure this doesn't happen again.

The tox targets pyXX-psql are renamed pyXX-postgresql to match all other jobs names.

Change-Id: I0e6cfb71cc53a47a11a12b5797fe262f9211ce22
(cherry picked from commit 5881c525a383588c9d83dbb9aab0bd89df3997d0)
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-04-24 06:40:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer/commit/4c5b9a732a553801002d3cfa36b181a3e3ddfb6d', 'message': "tests: fix tests for functional tests without dsvm

Currently functional tests pass in gate just because some calls are
done on real devstack, and passed by chance. We don't need dsvm at all
with pifpaf.

This change fixes this tests and add bindep.txt file for new gate jobs

commit_message:
tests: fix tests for functional tests without dsvm

Currently functional tests pass in gate just because some calls are
done on real devstack, and passed by chance. We don't need dsvm at all
with pifpaf.

This change fixes this tests and add bindep.txt file for new gate jobs
without dsvm will be setup to ensure this doesn't happen again.

Change-Id: I0e6cfb71cc53a47a11a12b5797fe262f9211ce22
(cherry picked from commit 5881c525a383588c9d83dbb9aab0bd89df3997d0)

commit_message:
Refactor Heat Patrole tests

Tempest has indicated plans to remove Heat tests and related
resources from their project and move them to a Heat Tempest
plugin. In preparation for this, Heat tests are being refactored
to use the Heat plugin instead.

Implements bp: use-heat-tempest-plugin
Co-Authored-By: Felipe Monteiro <felipe.monteiro@att.com>

Change-Id: I5df0fe09c8ec7c4e43d5d56fdce1fbb405117002
Depends-On: I6e9f909e4be5e0be94e910f3a1b0eb22bb74ee38

added_lines: import tempest.test from heat_integrationtests.common import clients from heat_integrationtests.common import exceptions as heat_excclass HeatConf(object): username = CONF.heat_plugin.username if username is None: raise heat_exc.InvalidCredentials(message="Requires heat_plugin " "credential configuration") admin_username = CONF.auth.admin_username password = CONF.heat_plugin.password if password is None: raise heat_exc.InvalidCredentials(message="Requires heat_plugin " "credentials configuration") admin_password = CONF.auth.admin_password tenant_name = CONF.heat_plugin.tenant_name if tenant_name is None: raise heat_exc.InvalidCredentials(message="Requires heat_plugin " "credential configuration") admin_tenant_name = CONF.auth.admin_project_name user_domain_id = CONF.heat_plugin.user_domain_id project_domain_id = CONF.heat_plugin.project_domain_id user_domain_name = CONF.heat_plugin.user_domain_name project_domain_name = CONF.heat_plugin.project_domain_name region = CONF.identity.region auth_url = CONF.identity.uri_v3 disable_ssl_certificate_validation = False ca_file = None class BaseOrchestrationRbacTest(tempest.test.BaseTestCase): def heat_setup(cls): conf = HeatConf() heat_mgr = clients.ClientManager(conf) # admin_heat_mgr = clients.ClientManager(conf, admin_credentials=True) return heat_mgr.orchestration_client @classmethod if not CONF.service_available.heat: raise cls.skipException("Heat support is required") cls.orchestration_client = cls.heat_setup()

commit_message:
tests: fix messaging driver

Since last oslo.config, an issue in our tests have showup.

We set a string on a MultiStrOpt, for example this results to have the
messaging driver looks like ["a", "e", "g", "i", "m", "n"] instead of
["messaging"]. I wonder how this have worked before...

This change fixes the drivers lists.

Change-Id: I973aa66f54b284fd87b1e48d43a2e459d760cbe3
(cherry picked from commit af8957eb6302c11e64f00649af6e02a7b50d2dda)

commit_message:
tests: fix messaging driver

Since last oslo.config, an issue in our tests have showup.

We set a string on a MultiStrOpt, for example this results to have the
messaging driver looks like ["a", "e", "g", "i", "m", "n"] instead of
["messaging"]. I wonder how this have worked before...

This change fixes the drivers lists.

(cherry picked from commit 52f561c88eca534813531efe749898bcaa79f9f5)
Change-Id: I973aa66f54b284fd87b1e48d43a2e459d760cbe3

commit_message:
Make rpc_backend not engine specific

The rpc_backend with kombu and oslo are being used by the executor
and event engine as well. This patch move the rpc_backend up one
level so it's not engine specific. Also Event engine has its own module
and the EventEngine class is defined in the engine module. This patch
moves the EventEngine to it's own base file in the event_engine module.

Implements: blueprint mistral-actions-run-by-engine

Change-Id: Ie814a26e05f5ca6bfba10f20a7d5921836aa7602

commit_message:
Tags and Metadata fields with unicode cannot be correctly displayed

Currently, Tags(list) and Metadata(dict) fields of instance will
firstly transformed to str using jsondump first when display. And
cannot be correctly transfomed and displayed afterwards.

This patch adds ensure_ascii=False to the transform function thus
those fields can be correctly tranformed and displayed afterwards.

Change-Id: Ib4e7a34f3b19db89280cc73053acbac8c8816f85
Closes-Bug: #1669683
(cherry picked from commit 07971152413c3aa94e87b16f562acf686b9c5f48)

commit_message:
Fix devstack python-novaclient warning

The following warning is emitted for every nova command using devstack,
stable/ocata.

    site-packages/novaclient/client.py:278:
        UserWarning: The 'tenant_id' argument is deprecated in Ocata and
        its use may result in errors in future releases. As 'project_id'
        is provided, the 'tenant_id' argument will be ignored.

See the following commit for related changes:

    Clarify meaning of project_id var
    9bbe5a87b7df62a7962debba5db7c96555da6761

Change-Id: Ifa5ed16f10a43c9961e98b03fc0535e12d7977ba
(cherry picked from commit 1a9bfc424a59b4f2675d607881a5f0b2605a3f06)

commit_message:
Bump minimums: osc-lib to 1.5.1 and os-client-config to 1.27.0

These are both required to fix some auth problems in OpenStackClient,
plus additional features/fixes for shade in os-client-config.

Change-Id: I46db007ee5169de4c4fd2dd50c5229e170910d9e

commit_message:
Add python-tricircleclient

- Is the library actively maintained?

  Yes, by the tricircle team

- Is the library good code?

  it has UT that guarantees its quality and code coverage

- Is the library python 3 compatible?

  Yes

- Is the library license compatible?

  Apache 2.0

- Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu
  latest / Fedora latest)?

  No

- Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries
  in ``global-requirements.txt``?

  No

- Is the library required for OpenStack project or related dev or
  infrastructure setup? (Answer to this should be Yes, of course)
  Which?

  Yes, by Tricircle project

Change-Id: I692e3b0f7b3833c978909a77caaa4a9bf64efa11

commit_message:
kolla_toolbox: allow docker api version to be specified

When docker-py is newer than docker daemon following
APIError may be raised:

client is newer than server (client API version: 1.24, server API version: 1.22)

So it's better to pass api_version='auto' to docker client,
so client will discover suitable version if not specified.

Change-Id: Ib747ed91b315ca762936a6efa6b71a29b2d2ae1e
Signed-off-by: Pavel Glushchak <pglushchak@virtuozzo.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/69/459269/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: api_version: description: - The version of the api for docker-py to use when contacting docker required: False type: str default: auto module_extra_vars=dict(type='json'), api_version=dict(required=False, type='str', default='auto') ) client = get_docker_client()( version=module.params.get('api_version'))

commit_message:
Remove deprecated oslo.config messages.

DeprecationWarning: Using the 'enforce_type' argument is deprecated in
version '4.0' and will be removed in version '5.0': The argument
enforce_type has changed its default value to True and then will be
removed completely.

This option have never been useful, and now the default is already True.
So we don't need to raise requirement for this.

Change-Id: I042a5d98748e2b2c6ee8307340aa6056bf0a1dfd

commit_message:
Ubuntu: pin puppetlabs-apt to 3.0.0

... because puppetlabs-rabbitmq doesn't work with 4.x.x and 4.0.0 is out
since yesterday, so we don't want to bump our CI yet.

Adds a validation to ensure at least one NTP source
is available.

Misconfigured or inaccessible NTP servers is a

or fail with debug output from ntpdate.

The heat boolean: ValidateNtp can be set to disable

Change-Id: Ie93f943b53bf3a1b60a536df4a28ae203d98988f
'}]
commit_message:
Validate NTP servers

Adds a validation to ensure at least one NTP source
is available.

Misconfigured or inaccessible NTP servers is a
common source of erratic behavior and failures. This
validation will ensure a NTP source is available
or fail with debug output from ntpdate.

The heat boolean: ValidateNtp can be set to disable
this check.

Change-Id: Ie93f943b53bf3a1b60a536df4a28ae203d98988f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/47/456747/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Define grammar for workload characterization
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-26 21:16:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/watcher-specs/commit/fd118ea1e27bb56ba72b54655bf37e45a64aa062', 'message': '[WIP]: Define grammar for workload characterization

As we run several workloads in cloud, we should be able to characterize such
workloads as input to watcher for ensuring Application QoS, placements and
consolidation.

An example of workload characterization is a weighted combination of CPU,
Memory or any other resource attributes like High IOPs, Network latency etc.

Scope of this blueprint is to come up with a grammar structure for defining
workload character.

commit_message:
Define grammar for workload characterization

As we run several workloads in cloud, we should be able to characterize such
workloads as input to watcher for ensuring Application QoS, placements and
consolidation.

An example of workload characterization is a weighted combination of CPU,
Memory or any other resource attributes like High IOPs, Network latency etc.

Scope of this blueprint is to come up with a grammar structure for defining
workload character.

Co-Authored-By: Chris Spencer <christopher.m.spencer@intel.com>
Co-Authored-By: Susanne Balle <sleipnir012@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Prashanth Hari <hvprash@gmail.com>
blueprint: workload-characterization-grammar
Change-Id: I6f43b49042371fc2feac17db2be5861a89fe5262

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================ Define grammar for workload characterization ============================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/watcher/+spec/workload-characterization-grammar Problem description =================== As we run several workloads in cloud, we should be able to characterize such workloads as input to watcher for ensuring Application QoS, placements and consolidation. An example of workload characterization is a weighted combination of CPU, Memory or any other resource attributes like High IOPs, Network latency etc. Scope of this blueprint is to come up with a grammar structure for defining workload character. Use Cases --------- When several applications are deployed in cloud, it becomes a challenge for cloud operators and tenants to ensure desired performance and QoS for the applications running in cloud. This requires application workload characterization and performance objectives, build optimization strategies based on the defined workload character. In short, a user should be able to define and map workload characteristics to the VMs for profiling and build strategies for performance optimizations. Project Priority ---------------- Not Defined Proposed change =============== Alternatives ------------ Data model impact ----------------- REST API impact --------------- Security impact --------------- Notifications impact -------------------- Other end user impact --------------------- Performance Impact ------------------ Other deployer impact --------------------- Developer impact ---------------- Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Intel and Walmart are working together on this blueprint. Primary assignee: Prashanth Hari (hvprash) Sameer Adhikari (tri2sing) Susanne Balle (sballe) Other contributors: Work Items ---------- Dependencies ============ Testing ======= Documentation Impact ==================== References ========== History =======

commit_message:
Add spec for cron based continuous audits

This patch set adds specification for cron based continuous audits
blueprint.

Partially-implements: blueprint cron-based-continuous-audits

Change-Id: I27d7b64e79e61eaa017a7fb25892d70a1b4a8dc1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/watcher-specs refs/changes/88/442388/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================ Cron-based continuous audits ============================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/watcher/+spec/cron-based-continuous-audits Problem description =================== Watcher can run continuous audits with specified by user interval. But time of next running isn't stored in database so it may cause some collisions when Watcher services are down. Meantime, using interval isn't flexible and user-friendly solution. There is industry standard like cron syntax that provides elastic way to schedule audit execute. Use Cases --------- * As an administrator, I want to use cron syntax to schedule audit execute. * As an administrator, I want be sure that Watcher will set up next time executing of audits properly. Proposed change =============== Watcher API already has 'interval' property in Audit object so we can use it to store cron like format. API is to check type of incoming interval and if it is string type then Watcher uses `croniter`_ module to set next run time. The second proposition is to provide persistence for current 'interval' column. To do it, we need to properly update next_run_time since its value may be less than current time. In this case, we may use the following algorithm: :: delta = timedelta(seconds= (interval - (current_time-old_next_run_time).seconds % interval)) next_run_time = current_time + delta For example, Watcher had to run audit at 7:30 am, but services went down and we have restored it only at 9:00 am. Using interval with 3600 value, Watcher has to set next run time at 9:30 am. Alternatives ------------ * Continue to use already provided interval. * Delete continuous audits after each maintenance mode and create new ones. Data model impact ----------------- * Type of interval column of Audit table should be changed to string type. * New column next_run_time has to be added to Audit table. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Alexander Chadin <alexchadin> Work Items ---------- * Add next_run_time column to Audit table. * Use croniter module to support cron-like syntax in Watcher. * Update python-watcherclient to support cron-like syntax. * Add logic to calculate values for next_run_time field. Dependencies ============ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/watcher/+spec/continuously-optimization Testing ======= Unit tests should be updated. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None History ======= None .. _croniter: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/croniter

Update docs theme configuration

Enable log-a-bug feature and add information on when document was built.

Disable pep8 check for doc/source/conf.py.

Change-Id: Ia86791ac69845572b2fbc536732afcf901bcf203
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-doc-tools refs/changes/52/461252/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # A few variables have to be set for the log-a-bug feature. # giturl: The location of conf.py on Git. Must be set manually. # gitsha: The SHA checksum of the bug description. Automatically extracted from git log. # bug_tag: Tag for categorizing the bug. Must be set manually. # These variables are passed to the logabug code via html_context. giturl = u'https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/openstack-doc-tools/tree/doc/source' git_cmd = "/usr/bin/git log | head -n1 | cut -f2 -d' '" gitsha = os.popen(git_cmd).read().strip('\n') bug_tag = u'openstack-doc-tools' html_context = {"gitsha": gitsha, "bug_tag": bug_tag, "giturl": giturl} # If not '', a 'Last updated on:' timestamp is inserted at every page bottom, # using the given strftime format. # So that we can enable "log-a-bug" links from each output HTML page, this # variable must be set to a format that includes year, month, day, hours and # minutes. html_last_updated_fmt = '%Y-%m-%d %H:%M'

commit_message:
Add 'schedule' to session schema

Currently we can create a new session with json
file that has no 'schedule' option successfully,
but when we add a new job to the session, it will
be failed with internal error. This patch add
'schedule' validation in session creating.

Change-Id: Ib092700d8d08d79a4708947eaad86ec48c24b4a9
Closes-Bug: #1679998

commit_message:
Add QoS bandwidth limit for instance ingress traffic

This patch introduces the new parameter "direction" to
the QoS bandwidth limit rule. It will allow the creation
of bandwidth limit rules for either ingress or egress
traffic. For backwards compatibility the default direction
will be egress.

DocImpact: Ingress bandwidth limit available for QoS
APIImpact: New type of parameter for QoS rule in neutron API

Change-Id: Ia13568879c2b6f80fb190ccafe7e19ca05b0c6a8
Partial-Bug: #1560961

commit_message:
Add external lock dir to glance api config

As we move to enabling glance-api to use a wsgi script that might be run
as multiple processes, there are a couple places where external
synchronization is necessary. To use this we need to set the lock_path
config option from oslo.concurrency so external locks will work.

Change-Id: I9a66a8636d12037ff9aa4fb73cc3f9b9343dd7e9

Current implementation does not work for ports that do not have an allowed address at creation time

Closes-Bug: #1687377

commit_message:
Fixes osc port set allowed-address for ports without previous set allowed address

Current implementation does not work for ports that do not have an allowed address at creation time
This fix makes sure you can add a port to allowed address when it is not set yet

Change-Id: Id3c43c4e22d20fcbd9f2316a19d19d620b561d0d
Closes-Bug: #1687377
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/54/461354/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Fix install guide filter:authtoken config example
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-06 23:02:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/dc4d788be9ccb29e8df16a2883f2f7bd13440d26', 'message': "Fix install guide filter:authtoken config example

The name of the default domain in keystone is 'Default', not 'default',
which is its ID. If a user copy and pastes the user_domain_name and
project_domain_name settings from example [filter:authtoken] section
in the install guide, the first time they run 'swift stat' they will
meet a 401 error because keystone is trying to look up domains by name
rather than ID. This patch corrects the docs so that they are
copy-and-paste-proof.

Change-Id: Ic595c2923b71d1c2ff2b4c9a773ea7742fdd029b
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-04-12 09:24:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/18dd1d9c1714cf7371c8c57f59a3a85d87723258', 'message': "Fix install guide filter:authtoken config example

The name of the default domain in keystone is 'Default', not 'default',
which is its ID. If a user copy and pastes the user_domain_name and
project_domain_name settings from example [filter:authtoken] section
in the install guide, the first time they run 'swift stat' they will
meet a 401 error because keystone is trying to look up domains by name
rather than ID. This patch corrects the docs so that they are
copy-and-paste-proof.

Change-Id: Ic595c2923b71d1c2ff2b4c9a773ea7742fdd029b
Closes-Bug: 1682059"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2017-04-28 13:07:22.000000000', 'files': ['install-guide/source/controller-include.txt', 'install-guide/source/controller-common_prerequisites.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/93ca16c558068d525dbbc0bb34d90d6bee976db0', 'message': "Fix install guide filter:authtoken config example

The name of the default domain in keystone is 'Default', not 'default',
which is its ID. If a user copy and pastes the user_domain_name and
project_domain_name settings from example [filter:authtoken] section
in the install guide, the first time they run 'swift stat' they will
meet a 401 error because keystone is trying to look up domains by name
rather than ID. This patch corrects the docs so that they are
copy-and-paste-proof, and also updates the keystone user creation
example to demonstrate the correct domain ID.

Change-Id: Ic595c2923b71d1c2ff2b4c9a773ea7742fdd029b
"}]
commit_message:
Fix install guide filter:authtoken config example

The name of the default domain in keystone is 'Default', not 'default',
which is its ID. If a user copy and pastes the user_domain_name and
project_domain_name settings from example [filter:authtoken] section
in the install guide, the first time they run 'swift stat' they will
meet a 401 error because keystone is trying to look up domains by name
rather than ID. This patch corrects the docs so that they are
copy-and-paste-proof, and also updates the keystone user creation
example to demonstrate the correct domain ID.

Change-Id: Ic595c2923b71d1c2ff2b4c9a773ea7742fdd029b

commit_message:
[M->N] Ensure mod_ssl is installed during upgrade.

In Newton mod_ssl is installed by default.  We make sure that during
upgrade this is done as well to avoid problem with the fix in
https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1682448

Change-Id: I49bd6f0017048fbab8a4011d5d7c3ffc6cda85b6
Related-Bug: #1682448

commit_message:
Unset the UpgradeInitCommand on converge

In the converge envs we unset the UpgradeInitCommon since we used
that for the N..O upgrades workflow. However an operator may have
also overridden the UpgradeInitCommand so we should unset that
too.

Closes-Bug: 1686918
Change-Id: I3b316d04b78a4ab1e3f9f69948e42e6fb0ad6632
(cherry picked from commit 7d87b8225bd640fee4b55fd66e793391526f6d54)

commit_message:
Rename user stories related repos

The Product Working Group has decided to cease using the term "user
stories" in favor of "development proposals" and to realign the
"userstory-dashboard" with the "featuretracker" name used for the
site where it's hosted. As a result, rename the following three Git
repositories:

  * openstack-infra/puppet-userstory_dashboard -> puppet-featuretracker

  * openstack-infra/userstory-dashboard -> featuretracker

  * openstack/openstack-user-stories -> development-proposals

See
http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/product_working_group/2017/product_working_group.2017-04-03-21.06.log.html#l-93
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/user-committee/2017-March/001902.html
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/user-committee/2017-April/001919.html
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/user-committee/2017-April/001929.html

Change-Id: Id6bb1a26da2b2f39ae5d1ce017062a13f1afc135
Depends-On: I3791f909e57a0b4f9211681e7e0faf9d539ca321
